H0.text: Low density is the property of matter in the initial moments of the universe that particle accelerators, such as the Large Hadron Collider in Europe, are designed to simulate by accelerating subatomic particles to great speeds, moving them in opposite directions at nearly the speed of light, and colliding them to recreate early‑universe conditions.

H1.text: High energy is the property of matter in the initial moments of the universe that particle accelerators, such as the Large Hadron Collider, are designed to simulate by accelerating subatomic particles to great speeds, moving them in opposite directions at nearly the speed of light, and colliding them to recreate the conditions that existed as the universe formed.

H2.text: Massive nuclei are the property of matter in the initial moments of the universe that particle accelerators, such as the Large Hadron Collider in Europe, are designed to simulate by accelerating subatomic particles to nearly the speed of light and colliding them.

H3.text: Circular movement is the property of matter in the initial moments of the universe that particle accelerators, such as the Large Hadron Collider, are designed to simulate by accelerating subatomic particles to great speeds, moving them in opposite directions at nearly the speed of light, and colliding them to recreate early‑universe conditions.

A4.text: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC), which had its first beam circulation on 10 September 2008, and is now the world's most energetic collider of protons.

A5.text: The Large Hadron Collider also became the most energetic collider of heavy ions after it began colliding lead ions.

A6.text: Scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory's Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider announced they had created quark–gluon plasma by colliding gold ions at nearly the speed of light, reaching temperatures of 4 trillion degrees Celsius.

A7.text: In the quark matter phase diagram, QGP is placed in the high-temperature, high-density regime, whereas ordinary matter is a cold and rarefied mixture of nuclei and vacuum.
